papers.title: Diagnostic Test-Beam-Line for the MESA Injector
institutions: For the planed Mainzer Energy-recovering Superconducting Accelerator (MESA) at the Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz a diagnostic test-beam-line has been build up. The beam-line comprises three analyzing stations to investigate space charge caused transverse emittance growth and helicity correlated asymmetries. Furthermore a circular deflecting cavity allows to measure the longitudinal bunch intensity profile. The components and the latest results will be described and an outlook towards further applications will be given.

papers.title: A Fast Rotating Wire Scanner for Use in High Intensity Accelerators
authors: Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-Based Sciences and Education

fast rotating wire scanner for use in accelerators where high beam currents would otherwise melt even carbon wires. This new design uses a simple planetary gear setup to rotate a tungsten or carbon wire

papers.title: Detection and Clearing of Trapped Ions in the High Current Cornell Photoinjector
authors: Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-Based Sciences and Education
We evaluate the effectiveness of three ion-clearing strategies in the Cornell high intensity photoinjector: DC clearing electrodes

and beam shaking. We present data from recent experiments where we directly measured the residual trapped ion density while employing these clearing methods. Several theoretical models have been developed to estimate the ion creation and clearing rates. The data is well explained by two independent simulation codes that track the motion of ions trapped in the electric field generated by the beam.

papers.title: GaAs Photocathode R&D: Energy Spread Measurements and the Nature of the Activated p-GaAs(Cs, O) Activation Layer
authors: Electron injector brightness is limited by the energy spread in the electrons emitted from a photocathode. Knowledge and understanding of the physical mechanisms underpinning this energy spread is critical in the development of high-performance electron sources
as is the ability to quantify this energy spread. In order to measure longitudinal and transverse photoelectron energy distribution curves
have developed a Transverse Energy Spread Spectrometer (TESS) which permits measurement of photoelectron energy spread for different photocathode types under varying conditions of degradation
temperature and illumination. We describe the operating principle of this equipment. Photocathode performance is strongly affected by surface structure
